sec.title: Background:
sec.p: Osteoporosis is a systemic skeletal disease characterized by a low bone mass and bone architectural derangements, leading to an increased fracture risk. Once osteoporosis has developed, then it is less likely to completely restore the bone strength of the patients. The prevalence of osteoporosis is increasing as the global population ages rapidly. Osteoporosis affects women more than men, and its incidence worldwide is very high.

sec.title: Objective:
sec.p: To estimate the proportion of postmenopausal Indian women at risk for osteoporosis using the Osteoporosis Self-Assessment Tool for Asians (OSTA), a validated screening tool”.

sec.title: Materials and Methods:
sec.p: The study was included 174 post-menopausal women; Osteoporosis self-assessment tool was explained to the subject. The height and weight were measured and put into OSTA formula ((body weight in kg – age in years) × 0.2). Administration of the score were monitor and OSTA was used to assess incidence of Osteoporosis.

sec.title: Results:
sec.p: The study result shows that in middle age women 90% low risk of osteoporosis and those BMI in between 20 to 30 the P value is <0.0001. In this age group no high risk of osteoporosis. In old age women having 18.51% high risk of osteoporosis and those BMI in between 19 to 21 is the P value 0.2.

sec.title: Conclusion:
sec.p: Indian The study concluded that overweight women was low risk for osteoporosis than normal and underweight women.

sec.title: INTRODUCTION
sec.p: Osteoporosis, a silent and progressive skeletal disorder with its leading complications, is associated with increased morbidity and mortality among the global population.[1] Osteoporosis is characterized by deranged bone architecture and increasing bone loss eventually leading to increased fracture risk with trivial falls.[2] Osteoporosis is found to affect predominately older and postmenopausal women however young women are susceptible due to underlying medical conditions, westernized foods, and increased inactivity. It poses a significant public concern due to its increased susceptibility to cause pain, immobility and fatigue eventually leading to functional dependence on the other household members.[3]

Epidemiological studies point out a steady increase in the osteoporosis with 23% prevalence in women compared to 11% in men.[4] Globally, osteoporosis affects approximately 200 million postmenopausal women, with Asian populations including India bearing a growing burden; studies estimate that 6.9% of Indian women are at risk of osteoporosis, while 34% have osteopenia.[5] Compared to Western populations, studies indicate that Indian women experience earlier onset and higher prevalence of osteoporotic fractures,[6] underscoring the need for region-specific risk assessment tools. A recent systematic review demonstrates a staggering prevalence of osteoporosis, estimated to affect 8%–62% of postmenopausal Indian women.[4] Hence there needs to be easy and accessible region-specific screening tools to early detection and address of osteoporosis among Indian postmenopausal women.

Population based observational studies claim several determinants to be the risk factors of osteoporosis however inconsistent: Poor socioeconomic status, poor lifestyle factors (smoking and alcohol), poor balanced diet lacking in minerals and Vitamin D, and lack of optimized movement behaviors (sufficient physical activity and less sedentary behavior) especially outdoor activities.[7] Further, underlying chronic diseases including cardiometabolic, endocrine, and neurological disorders increase chances of immobility, muscle wasting, and increased bone catabolism eventually leading to osteoporosis risk among postmenopausal women.[8] Hence early detection of osteoporosis among postmenopausal becomes inevitable in avoiding the future risk of fractures, functional dependence, and poor quality of life.

While dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry (DXA) remains the gold standard for diagnosing osteoporosis, its limited accessibility in resource-constrained regions of India hinders widespread screening.[3] To overcome this challenge, the World Health Organization and subsequent researchers have introduced simplified tools such as the Osteoporosis Self-Assessment Tool for Asians (OSTA), which estimates osteoporosis risk using only age and body weight.[9] OSTA was developed in eight Asian countries as mentioned in previous study,[10] also has demonstrated fair to excellent performance (AUC 0.693–0.727) in different Indian regions.[1112] This study therefore utilizes OSTA as a validated proxy to estimate osteoporosis risk and its associated factors among postmenopausal Indian women. By doing so, it aims to offer an affordable and scalable tool aligned with India’s public health priorities to identify women at risk and facilitate early preventive measures.

sec.title: METHODS
sec.p: The present cross-sectional study was conducted between January 2023 and January 2024. The study protocol was approved by the Institutional Ethics Committee. The study was reported as per the guidelines of STROBE.[13]

sec.title: Study design
sec.p: The present observational study was administered in community-dwelling adults to explore the osteoporosis risk among postmenopausal Indian women. The survey was continued with the written consent through E-mail of the concerned participants.

sec.title: Sample size determination
sec.p: With a level of confidence of 95%, we required 156 postmenopausal women to detect an estimated 8% proportion of women at high risk for osteoporosis, as assessed by OSTA at a 4.5% precision[9] and a total of 170 participants with an added loss at a confidence interval of 3%–13%. The sample size was estimated using Scalex SP Excel add (version 1.0.1, https://sites.google.com/view/sr-ln/ssc).[14]

sec.title: Participants
sec.p: The participants were community-dwelling adults identified through social media. To be eligible, women must be middle-aged or older. The potential participants with a history of fracture, ankylosing spondyloarthropathy, and hormonal replacement therapy in recent 6 months were excluded [Figure 1].

caption.p: Flowchart demonstrating the inclusion and exclusion of the participants

sec.title: Outcome
sec.p: Osteoporosis risk was assessed using OSTA, the screening algorithm is used which is based on age (years) and body weight (kg). OSTA index is calculated using the formula: OSTA index = [body weight (kg) − age (years)] × 0.2. The resulting value is truncated to an integer and categorized into: (1) Low risk: >−1; (2) medium risk: −4–−1; (3) High risk: <−4.

sec.title: Procedure
sec.p: The study was initiated after the approval of the Institutional Ethical Committee. The study invitations were shared across social media and local newspapers and potential participants with the eligibility criteria mentioned above were invited to the study. Customized questionnaires with baseline demographic data and OSTA were developed in the Google Forms. Once the participants expressed their consents, the bespoke questionnaire was shared, and the appropriate responses were collected. The questionnaires with missed data were also included and multiple imputations were carried out.

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: The continuous data (demographic variables) and nominal variables (risk percentages) were presented as mean ± standard deviation and number (%) as the data were normalized. Association between body mass index (BMI), sedentary lifestyles, and OSTA scores were analyzed using Pearson’s correlation tests. The signficiance was set at P < 0.05 and all the data were analyzed using SPSS version 22.0 (IBM Corporation, Armonk, NY, USA).

sec.title: RESULTS
sec.p: The total number of 174 postmenopausal women participated in the study. The study was conducted using osteoporosis self-assessment tool. The data were entered in Microsoft Excel.

sec.title: Baseline characteristics
sec.p: Table 1 shows the baseline characteristics of the participants included in the study. The mean age was found to 53.93 ± 8.47 years and BMI was 24.29 ± 3.44 kg/m2. The OSTA scores were moderately high. The majority of the participants were found to be at high risk of osteoporosis (n = 155, 89%). Thirty-eight percent (n = 67) were found to be sedentary.

sec.title: Proportion of postmenopausal women at risk for osteoporosis based on Osteoporosis Self-Assessment Tool for Asians
sec.p: When age-wise comparison was made who were at the risk of osteoporosis, the present study found 55.5% and 18.51% of the participants aged above 60 years were at moderate and high risk, respectively, based on the self-evaluation tool, OSTA. Here, 90% middle-aged women in low risk, 26% of old age women in low risk, 10% middle-aged women in moderate risk, 55.55% of old age women in moderate risk, and 18% of old age women in high risk of osteoporosis [Figure 2].

caption.p: Percent of risk factors in middle and old age women

sec.title: Association of body mass index and the Osteoporosis Self-Assessment Tool for Asians scores
sec.p: Higher BMI was found to have high OSTA scores [Figure 3]. When the BMI measures were associated with the OSTA scores, similar trend was shown with BMI more than 21 kg/m2 was associated with a higher risk of OSTA scores. The Pearson test showed a moderate association (r = 0.44, P < 0.001) between BMI and OSTA scores.

caption.p: Association between body mass index and Osteoporosis Self-Assessment Tool for Asians scores (a) Box plots, (b) Scatter plot. OSTA: Osteoporosis Self-Assessment Tool for Asians, BMI: Body mass index

sec.title: Sedentary lifestyle versus osteoporosis risk
sec.p: Thirty-eight percent of middle-aged participants and 40% of older participants (>60 years) who were sedentary were found to have a higher risk of osteoporosis. However, Pearson tests revealed no significant association (P = 0.02, r = 0.77) between sedentary lifestyle and osteoporosis risk [Figure 4].

caption.p: Differences in the Osteoporosis Self-Assessment Tool for Asians scores among nonsedentary and sedentary individuals. OSTA: Osteoporosis Self-Assessment Tool for Asians

sec.title: DISCUSSION
sec.p: The present cross-sectional study aimed to explore the proportion of Indian women who may be at osteoporosis risk and its potential determinants (BMI and sedentary lifestyle). The present study found that 18% of the Indian women are found to have a higher risk. Increased BMI and age were found to be strongly associated with the OSTA scores while a sedentary lifestyle was found to be a least determinant.

We found BMI and osteoporosis risk are positively associated with each other, which is in liaison with previous studies which concluded obesity to be a protective factor against osteoporosis risk due to its loading in the long bones.[3] Loading mechanically the long bones were found to be the sole reason behind the strong association of BMI and the OSTA scores.[15] Our study is contrary to contemporary studies have shown no significant relation between BMI with BMD in women.[16] However, our findings should be further substantiated with the longitudinal studies.

Our study found that a substantial proportion of Indian postmenopausal women were classified as moderate-to-high risk for osteoporosis according to OSTA. Our study finding is in liaison with the previous studies that has established the osteoporosis risk of 20% among Indian postmenopausal women.[17] Vitamin D deficiency, malnourishment leading to poor calcium, women inequalities, and early medical diagnosis and management are perceived to be the reasons for higher osteoporosis risk.[17] Although the OSTA uses body weight rather than BMI, several studies have demonstrated that low BMI is significantly associated with lower BMD and increased risk of osteoporosis.[1819] In our study, BMI was evaluated to explore its relationship with OSTA-classified risk, not as a standalone diagnostic criterion.

In our study, the readers should carefully interpret that OSTA was not used to diagnose osteoporosis but to stratify participants into low, medium, and high-risk categories, enabling identification of individuals who may benefit from further diagnostic evaluation through DXA.[2021] This aligns with its intended purpose as a triage tool in settings where access to definitive testing is limited. Simplified triage tools like OSTA may be helpful in reducing subjectivity and may prioritize patients for further BMD measurements, ensuring efficient use of healthcare resources.[122022] Thus, OSTA may play an imperative role in bridging the gap between population risk identification and targeted resource utilization for osteoporosis diagnosis and prevention.

Our study has a significant limitation in the study design as the cross-sectional trial do not render any causal-effect relations.[23] Further, we reached the participants through E-mail which means that only the educated population were able to reach while significant proportion of community-dwelling participants remained unexplored. Besides the osteoporosis risk was estimated using OSTA questionnaire with inherent recall and social desirability biases.[24] Even though OSTA does not indicate confirmed osteoporosis prevalence, it provides a meaningful screening estimate to identify individuals needing further diagnostic evaluation.

sec.title: CONCLUSION
sec.p: Our findings indicate that over one-third of postmenopausal Indian women may be at increased risk for osteoporosis when assessed using the OSTA tool. While OSTA cannot confirm diagnosis, it serves as a valuable screening method to guide prioritization for definitive testing such as DXA. Our study highlights the importance of incorporating simple, validated screening tools like OSTA into primary health care and community outreach programs, especially in resource-limited settings. Furthermore, the study demonstrates the utility of OSTA as an effective self-assessment method for identifying early osteoporosis risk in Indian postmenopausal women, where access to advanced diagnostic tools such as DXA remains limited.
